Louisville actress remembers Mike Nichols

Louisville actress Elizabeth Morton on working with the late Mike Nichols in "Death of a Salesman"

Louisville actress remembers Mike Nichols

Louisville Arts Bureau

Elizabeth Kramer, ekramer@courier-journal.com 9:06 p.m. EST November 20, 2014

Director Mike Nichols and wife Diane Sawyer in 2009.(Photo: Michael Loccisano, Getty Images.)

Tags

  • Mike Nichols
CONNECT 2 TWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

Actress and Lousiville native Elizabeth Morton.(Photo: Deborah Lopez)

While the director Mike Nichols' most obvious connection to Louisville was his wife journalist Diane Sawyer, a Louisville actor got to work with him just a few years ago. Elizabeth Morton was in the 2012 Broadway revival of Arthur Miller's "Death of a Salesman" which Nichols, who died Wednesday at the age of 83, directed.

On Thursday, she wrote, to say that she didn't know him well but regarded herself as fortunate to have worked with him in a Tony Award-winning show even playing Letta, a call girl, and a role she called small. But the day after Nichols' death, the memories loomed large.

"I could simply be there in the rehearsal room, as a member of that incredible ensemble (it included Philip Seymour Hoffman as Willy), and watch Mike Nichols work. He had just turned 80 and was overflowing with love for the play and for all of us," she wrote. "He gave gifts with carefully handwritten notes and threw parties and was often moved to tears at rehearsal and at the theatre. He also, of course, told fantastic stories and was always generous with his clever wit."

Today, she also has a script from the show with many of Nichols' quotes written in it and a photo of a bouquet she received on Valentine's Day, 2012, when she was getting ready for the first preview performance of "Death of a Salesman."

Morton posed that photo on her Facebook page Thursday with the following memories: "When we went backstage that night, there were bouquets of different color roses EVERYWHERE. All from Mike," Morton wrote. "Every actor, every crew member got a

bouquet. So of course it was hilarious that the note to accompany my bouquet said, 'Liz, will you be my Valentine? You're the only one.' Today, all the flowers are for you, sir."

Morton acknowledged she didn't' know him well, but still cherished having the chance to work for him.

"I will always be grateful that I got to witness first-hand a love-filled master at work," she wrote.

Reporter Elizabeth Kramer can be reached at (502) 582-4682. Follow her on Twitter at @arts_bureau.
